case_vignette: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my right eye while watching TV about 30 minutes ago, and I can't see anything with it.
Have you had any similar symptoms before?
No, this sudden loss of vision in my right eye has never happened to me before.
Have you had any recent headaches or dizziness?
No, I haven't had any recent headaches or dizziness.
Have you had any recent changes in your vision or any eye pain?
Before this happened, I didn't notice any changes in my vision and I haven't felt any eye pain.
Have you had any recent changes in your medications or any allergies?
I've had trouble sticking to my medication routine.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my diet or lifestyle.
Have you had any recent family history of eye conditions?
I'm just a patient and I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
Final Diagnosis: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
